nodes.text: Machine learning classifiers (KNN, Random Forest, SVM) can be used to detect lung cancer from CT images and improve early diagnosis
The study implements an image-processing based multi-stage classification pipeline in MATLAB that performs enhancement, segmentation, and classification to detect and stage lung cancer

Dataset: 500 CT images sampled from LIDC-IDRI (NIH-NCI) were used, with additional small validation sets from AHRC and AIMS hospitals; images downsampled from 512x512x3 to 256x and split 70% train / 30% test

Image pre-processing applied included CLAHE, Wiener, adaptive Gaussian, Gaussian and Gabor filtering, plus contrast enhancement, color space modification, scaling, thresholding and marker-controlled watershed segmentation

Model training: KNN uses Euclidean distance with parameter K; SVM constructs maximal margin hyperplane; Random Forest ensembles many decision trees with bootstrap sampling and majority voting; 5-fold cross-validation was used for evaluation
Performance metrics computed include accuracy, precision, recall, F1-score, true positive rate, false positive rate, sensitivity, specificity, FAR and FRR
The processing pipeline first detects presence of cancerous regions, then classifies malignancy into early, intermediate and advanced stages through sequential segmentation and classification steps
Experimental workflow and system diagram outline sequential stages: image acquisition, preprocessing, segmentation, feature extraction, classifier training and staging
Clinical validation: small sample sets from AHRC and AIMS were used and supervised by an AIMS radiologist to confirm model outputs
Assumption: Early detection of lung cancer via imaging and computational methods can improve treatment outcomes and survival
Result: SVM achieved average accuracy 95.06% across 5-fold cross-validation with average precision 0.95, recall 0.99 and average F1 around 0.98 (AUC > 0.99 reported per class)
Result: KNN achieved average accuracy 86.89% across 5 folds with average precision 0.84 and average F1 about 0.91
Result: Random Forest achieved average accuracy 81.96% across 5 folds with average precision 0.78 and average F1 about 0.87
Conclusion: SVM outperforms KNN and Random Forest on this dataset for lung cancer detection and staging, suggesting SVM is most suitable among tested methods for this task

Limitation: Study used a relatively small sample of 500 images and limited external validation samples which may limit generalizability and robustness across diverse populations and imaging conditions
Future work: Authors propose to collect larger, more diverse datasets spanning different demographics and cancer stages to improve model reliability and performance
